content.p: This is a collection of proverbs and saying that are common in the Raku community.

As context, Larry Wall was the designer of both languages. Damian Conway worked closely with him during the design of Raku. Damian's most prominent role was to interpret and explain what Larry had said.
This is a series of Perl saying compared with Raku Proverbs.

div.blockquote:
Perl Make the Easy Things Easy, and the Hard Things Possible This is likely a paraphrase of Alan Kay's quote Simple things should be simple, complex things should be possible.
Larry Wall

Raku For Raku, ... we aimed a little higher:
Easy things should be trivial Hard things should be easy; Impossible things should be (merely) hard.
Damian Conway

Perl There's More Than One Way To Do ItLarry Wall
Larry Wall

Raku There's More Than One Way To Do It
But Some Ways Are More Equal Than Others.
Damian Conway

ul.li: TMTOWTDI Acronym for "There's More Than One Way To Do It" (pronounced "Tim Toady")
SWAMETO Acronym for "Some Ways Are More Equal Than Others" (pronounced "swam to", as in "Tim Toady swam to...")

div.blockquote:
Perl Perl is the Swiss Army Chainsaw of Unix.
Henry SpencerHenry Spencer, the creator of the original regex library, was paraphrasing the saying that lex was "the Swiss-army knife of Unix programming"

Raku [Raku is] more like a Swiss army machine shop. It really gives you a lot of tools, some of which are dangerous, but it lets you get your job done very quickly.Larry Wall
Larry Wall

content.blockquote:
Raku is optimised for Fun
Audrey Tang
content.h2: Less than Awesome is a bug!
content.blockquote:
Any Raku error message that is LTA (“Less Than Awesome”) is officially considered to be a bug!
Damian Conway
content.p: When Raku was first created, it was created as version 6 of Perl. Eventually it took on enough life of its own to be given the name Raku. However, sometime around that point, Larry Wall, the creator of Perl, sadly had to withdraw from the community. I've thus substituted the name "Raku" in instead of Perl, but the sources will say "Perl". You can tell when I've done this by the [ ] around Raku.
content.blockquote:
How does [Raku] put the focus onto the creativity of the programmer? Very simple. [Raku] is humble. It doesn't try to tell the programmer how to program. It lets the programmer decide what rules today, and what sucks. It doesn't have any theoretical axes to grind. And where it has theoretical axes, it doesn't grind them. [Raku] doesn't have any agenda at all, other than to be maximally useful to the maximal number of people. To be the duct tape of the Internet, and of everything else. You've heard the joke, I'm sure. How is duct tape like the Force? It has a light side, and a dark side, and it holds the universe together.
Larry Wall, designer of Perl and Raku

Complexity is intrinsically irreducible…but extrinsically redistributable. [Raku] tries to put the complexity where it will do the least harm, and where its victims may have the best chance of surviving it.
Damian Conway

True greatness is measured by how much freedom you give to others, not by how much you can coerce others to do what you want.
Larry Wall

blockquote.div: DWIM in an acronym for "Do What I Mean", the principle that something should just do what you want it to do without an undue amount of fuss. A bit of code that does "dwimming" is a "dwimmer". Dwimming can require a great deal of behind-the-scenes magic, which (if it doesn't stay properly behind the schenes) is called a dweomer instead.
